comment.author: 26881258@N07
comment._content: Great picture of an early dirigible, maybe 1904. I will show the picture to experts in this field of aviation history, but the name is misspelled it was Roy Knabenshue (1875-1960)

comment.author: 26881258@N07
comment._content: As promised I would consult an expert in early dirigible history and I got far more detailed information about the type of machine and the actual place and time. The picture shows the "California Arrow" designed and built by Captain Baldwin. The dirigible was flown by Roy Knabenshue. Machines were continually modified and this picture shows the second modification fitted with a 8 hp (!) Curtiss engine. The location is Chutes Park in Los Angeles, a baseball station. We are looking in at 30 January 1905. Flyers in those times needed to be very courageous as they only could stand up on small wooden platform in the metal tube construction underneath the gas envelope. Newspapers of the time reported the marvel of flying extensively. As an example here is a reference to a report in the Los Angeles Herald which reports on the event and gives extra pictures covering the event. [chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042462/1905-01-30/ed-...]
